ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about some history of Roman type and printing presses. I feel I didn't actually learn much about typography though besides seeing the occasional compilation the professor made. My classmates were talented.
rudiments of Western typography, how to typeset a piece of text
I learned the fundamentals of typography and how to utilize text to convey meaning within my designs.
designing print matter, books, posters, InDesign tricks

How to consider form of typefaces, layout, and placement when making graphical designs. Learned about the history of graphic design and typography as well as how to use programs such as InDesign and Illustrator.
Book typesetting, expressive typography, science versus artistry of typography, how to create and program letterforms, brief history of typography

I learned valuable information on typography design in terms of typeface selection, typeface history, designing composition with type, and general graphic design information. I had also gained experience with getting feedback and critiques throughout phases of work as well as experience on how it feels to work as a graphic designer by how the assignments are set up and the crossing over of due dates.

I learned how to typeset text in print and digital formats, and how subtle typographical choices can impact the overall reading or viewing experience. I learned how to create my own typeface, print and bind a book, and select typefaces. We also did a broad survey of the evolution of typography through history by researching and presenting on a notable typographer/typeface.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The professor said the class readings were optional/only supplementary, but when I actually started to read them I learned much more about the field than actually going to class. The actual class consisted of showing up with pictures and staring at them, really. Each class was a crit, and when it is two hours a class, twice weekly, that quickly becomes like pulling teeth. If we'd actively made things in class, focused on new developments in the field, even if we'd been assigned any of those supplementary readings I think things would have gone smoother/felt more grounded/the class would be less "show up, hear opinions and leave".

The assignments felt poorly organized; the rational for this was that as graphic artists, overlapping responsibilities are something we'd have to get used to....but we're college students. Overlapping responsibilities are all we have.

Strengths: course goes through a gamut of exercises
Weaknesses: was very Euro-centric, little to no information on other modes of typography or typesetting; even out of European design, seemed very German-centric and most crits given were entirely from that perspective, not many hands-on exercises in class (Alice just kind of talks at you a lot) which made it boring a lot of the time
the guest critic wasn't very helpful
It was fine, just think the course should be relabeled "Western Typography" or something to be more accurate for students when selecting courses
This is such a great course! You get a lot of one-on-one critiques, which helps to determine where your work needs improvement.
critique was insightful and helpful

I think some of the auxiliary assignments (drawing letterforms and lines) were a lot of work that would be great to have been optional. It was great that the submission timeline for them were flexible but I feel like I didn't get much out of them. Otherwise, I really loved the assignments.

Strengths: good project design and timelines, professor was very helpful and easy to reach about any questions
Weaknesses: crits often went over and weren't very constructive, mostly things that students liked with professor feedback at the end

Strengths: great professor and TA, helpful critiques, practical assignments
Weaknesses: too many little assignments peppered in between the main projects

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only if you're truly head over heels for Helvetica.

No, it was really boring and hard to stay awake through each class
I also think that the other graphic design faculty are just much better at giving clear crits that improve your piece

If you're interested in Typography, you should just take Henk's class in the Spring
Yes! If you're interested in graphic design, this course is a must.
absolutely! Professor Chung is wonderful and provides feedback on everything

I'd definitely recommend this course to another student. ART 132 and ART 264 are awesome and a nice change of pace from requirements as a non-art major. Assignments are fun, you learn A TON, and the class discussions are great.
Yes if you are pursuing the graphic design concentration in the art major! Essential foundation to typographic work
Yes, if you are an art major especially with a graphic design focus this class will grow you significantly.
Yes - would recommend for any student interested in typography and/or looking to gain a deeper appreciation for the art and craft of type-making and -setting.
